dPBE: Discrete Population Balance Equations
  • PSD_opt
  • opt_algo module
  • View page source

opt_algo moduleÔÉÅ

Calculate the difference between the PSD of the simulation results and the experimental data. Minimize the difference by optimization algorithm to obtain the kernel of PBE.

class opt_algo.opt_algo[source]ÔÉÅ

Bases: object

Class definition for calculations within optimization process class.

AttributesÔÉÅ

n_iterint, optional

Number of iterations of the optimization process. Default is 100.

delta_flagstr, optional

Which data from the PSD is used for the calculation. Default is ‚Äòq3‚Äô. Options include:

  • ‚Äòq3‚Äô: Number density distribution

  • ‚ÄòQ3‚Äô: Cumulative distribution

  • ‚Äòx_10‚Äô: Particle size corresponding to 10% cumulative distribution

  • ‚Äòx_50‚Äô: Particle size corresponding to 50% cumulative distribution

  • ‚Äòx_90‚Äô: Particle size corresponding to 90% cumulative distribution

cost_func_typestr, optional

Method for calculating the PSD difference. Default is ‚ÄòMSE‚Äô. Options include:

  • ‚ÄòMSE‚Äô: Mean Squared Error

  • ‚ÄòRMSE‚Äô: Root Mean Squared Error

  • ‚ÄòMAE‚Äô: Mean Absolute Error

  • ‚ÄòKL‚Äô: Kullback‚ÄìLeibler divergence (Only q3 and Q3 are compatible with KL)

calc_init_Nbool, optional

Whether to use experimental data to calculate initial conditions. If False, the initial conditions for PBE need to be defined manually. Default is False.

calc_delta(corr_beta=None, alpha_prim=None, scale=1, sample_num=1, exp_data_path=None)[source]ÔÉÅ

Calculate the difference (delta) of PSD.

  • This method first calls calc_pop() to calculate the PBE under the current kernel.

  • Then calls calc_delta_tem() to calculate delta corresponding to experimental data.

ParametersÔÉÅ

corr_betafloat

Collision frequency correction factor for agglomeration in PBE.

alpha_primarray

Collision efficiency for agglomeration in PBE.

scaleint, optional. Default 1.

The actual return result is delta*scale. delta is absolute and always positive. Setting scale to 1 is suitable for optimizers that look for minimum values, and -1 is suitable for those that look for maximum values.

sample_numint, optional. Default 1.

Set how many sets of experimental data are used simultaneously for optimization.

exp_data_pathstr

path for experimental data.

calc_delta_agg(corr_agg=None, scale=1, sample_num=1, exp_data_path=None)[source]ÔÉÅ

Calculate the difference (delta) of PSD.

  • The function is exactly the same as calc_delta(), but receives corr_agg (agglomeration rate). Then calls ~.return_syth_beta to compute the equivalent corr_beta and alpha_prim.

ParametersÔÉÅ

corr_aggarray

Agglomeration rate in PBE.

scaleint, optional. Default 1.

The actual return result is delta*scale. delta is absolute and always positive. Setting scale to 1 is suitable for optimizers that look for minimum values, and -1 is suitable for those that look for maximum values.

sample_numint, optional. Default 1.

Set how many sets of experimental data are used simultaneously for optimization.

exp_data_pathstr

path for experimental data.

calc_delta_tem(sample_num, exp_data_path, scale, pop)[source]ÔÉÅ

Loop through all the experimental data and calculate the average diffences.

ParametersÔÉÅ

sample_numint, optional. Default 1.

Set how many sets of experimental data are used simultaneously for optimization.

exp_data_pathstr

path for experimental data.

poppop.population

Instance of the PBE.

ReturnsÔÉÅ

(delta_sum * scale) / x_uni_numfloat

Average value of PSD‚Äôs difference for corresponding to all particle sizes.

optimierer(method='BO', init_points=4, sample_num=1, hyperparameter=None, exp_data_path=None)[source]ÔÉÅ

Optimize the corr_beta and alpha_prim based on calc_delta(). Results are saved in corr_beta_opt and alpha_prim_opt.

ParametersÔÉÅ

methodstr

Which algorithm to use for optimization.

init_pointsint, optional. Default 4.

Number of steps for random exploration in BayesianOptimization.

sample_numint, optional. Default 1.

Set how many sets of experimental data are used simultaneously for optimization.

exp_data_pathstr

path for experimental data.

ReturnsÔÉÅ

delta_optfloat

Optimized value of the objective.

optimierer_agg(method='BO', init_points=4, sample_num=1, hyperparameter=None, exp_data_path=None)[source]ÔÉÅ

Optimize the corr_agg based on calc_delta_agg(). Results are saved in corr_agg_opt.

ParametersÔÉÅ

methodstr

Which algorithm to use for optimization.

init_pointsint, optional. Default 4.

Number of steps for random exploration in BayesianOptimization.

sample_numint, optional. Default 1.

Set how many sets of experimental data are used simultaneously for optimization.

exp_data_pathstr

path for experimental data.

ReturnsÔÉÅ

delta_optfloat

Optimized value of the objective.

return_syth_beta(corr_agg)[source]ÔÉÅ

Calculate and return a synthetic beta value.

This method calculates the maximum value of corr_agg, takes its logarithm to base 10, rounds it up to the nearest integer, and returns 10 raised to the power of this integer.

ParametersÔÉÅ

corr_aggarray

The correction factors for aggregation.

ReturnsÔÉÅ

float

The synthetic beta value

cost_fun(data_exp, data_mod)[source]ÔÉÅ

Calculate the difference(cost) between experimental and model data.

This method supports multiple cost function types including Mean Squared Error (MSE), Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE), Mean Absolute Error (MAE), and Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence.

ParametersÔÉÅ

data_exparray

The experimental data.

data_modarray

The data generated by the simulation.

ReturnsÔÉÅ

float

The calculated cost based on the specified cost function type.

read_exp(exp_data_path)[source]ÔÉÅ

Reads experimental data from a specified path and processes it.

ParametersÔÉÅ

exp_data_pathstr

Path to the experimental data.

ReturnsÔÉÅ

tuple of array

  • x_uni_exp: An array of unique particle sizes.

  • sumN_uni_exp: An array of sum of number concentrations for the unique particle sizes.

function_noise(ori_data)[source]ÔÉÅ

Adds noise to the original data based on the specified noise type.

The method supports four types of noise: Gaussian (‚ÄòGaus‚Äô), Uniform (‚ÄòUni‚Äô), Poisson (‚ÄòPo‚Äô), and Multiplicative (‚ÄòMul‚Äô). The type of noise and its strength are determined by the noise_type and noise_strength attributes, respectively.

ParametersÔÉÅ

ori_dataarray

The original data to which noise will be added.

ReturnsÔÉÅ

array

The noised data.

NotesÔÉÅ

  • Gaussian noise is added with mean 0 and standard deviation noise_strength.

  • Uniform noise is distributed over [-noise_strength/2, noise_strength/2).

  • Poisson noise uses noise_strength as lambda (expected value of interval).

  • Multiplicative noise is Gaussian with mean 1 and standard deviation noise_strength, and it is multiplied by the original data instead of being added.

KDE_fit(x_uni_ori, data_ori, bandwidth='scott', kernel_func='epanechnikov')[source]ÔÉÅ

Fit a Kernel Density Estimation (KDE) to the original data.

This method applies KDE to the original data using specified bandwidth and kernel function.

ParametersÔÉÅ

x_uni_oriarray

The unique values of the data variable, must be a one-dimensional array.

data_oriarray

The original data corresponding to x_uni_ori.

bandwidthstr, optional

The bandwidth to use for the kernel density estimation. Defaults to ‚Äòscott‚Äô.

kernel_funcstr, optional

The kernel function to use for KDE. Defaults to ‚Äòepanechnikov‚Äô.

ReturnsÔÉÅ

sklearn.neighbors.kde.KernelDensity

The fitted KDE model.

KDE_score(kde, x_uni_new)[source]ÔÉÅ

Evaluate the KDE model on new data points and normalize the results.

ParametersÔÉÅ

kdesklearn.neighbors.kde.KernelDensity

The fitted KDE model from KDE_fit().

x_uni_new :array

New unique data points where the KDE model is evaluated.

ReturnsÔÉÅ

array

The smoothed and normalized data based on the KDE model.

create_1d_pop(disc='geo')[source]ÔÉÅ

Instantiate one-dimensional populations for both non-magnetic (NM) and magnetic (M) particles.

calc_pop(pop, corr_beta, alpha_prim, t_vec=None)[source]ÔÉÅ

Configure and calculate the PBE.

set_comp_para(R01_0='r0_005', R03_0='r0_005', dist_path_NM=None, dist_path_M=None, R_NM=2.9e-07, R_M=2.9e-07)[source]ÔÉÅ

Set component parameters for non-magnetic and magnetic particle.

Configures the particle size distribution (PSD) parameters from provided paths or sets default values.

ParametersÔÉÅ

R01_0str, optional

Key for accessing the initial radius of NM particles from the PSD dictionary. Defaults to ‚Äòr0_005‚Äô.

R03_0str, optional

Key for accessing the initial radius of M particles from the PSD dictionary. Defaults to ‚Äòr0_005‚Äô.

dist_path_NMstr, optional

Path to the file containing the PSD dictionary for NM particles. If None, default radii are used.

dist_path_Mstr, optional

Path to the file containing the PSD dictionary for M particles. If None, default radii are used.

R_NMfloat, optional

Default radius for NM particles if dist_path_NM is not provided. Defaults to 2.9e-7.

R_Mfloat, optional

Default radius for M particles if dist_path_M is not provided. Defaults to 2.9e-7.

calc_all_R()[source]ÔÉÅ

Calculate the radius for particles in all PBEs.

set_init_N(sample_num, exp_data_paths, init_flag)[source]ÔÉÅ

Initialize the number concentration N for 1D populations based on experimental data.

ParametersÔÉÅ

sample_numint

The number of sets of experimental data used for initialization.

exp_data_pathslist of str

Paths to the experimental data for initialization.

init_flagstr

The method to use for initialization: ‚Äòint‚Äô for interpolation or ‚Äòmean‚Äô for averaging the initial sets.

set_init_N_1D(pop, sample_num, exp_data_path, init_flag)[source]ÔÉÅ

Initialize the number concentration N for a single 1D population using experimental data.

It processes the experimental data to align with the population‚Äôs discrete size grid, using either interpolation or averaging based on the init_flag. Supports processing multiple samples of experimental data for averaging purposes.

ParametersÔÉÅ

poppop.population

The population instance (either NM or M) to initialize.

sample_numint

Number of experimental data sets used for initialization.

exp_data_pathstr

Path to the experimental data file.

init_flagstr

Initialization method: ‚Äòint‚Äô for interpolation, ‚Äòmean‚Äô for averaging.

calc_v_uni(pop)[source]ÔÉÅ

Calculate unique volume values for a given population.

calc_x_uni(pop)[source]ÔÉÅ

Calculate unique particle diameters from volume values for a given population.

re_calc_distribution(x_uni, q3=None, sum_uni=None, flag='all')[source]ÔÉÅ

Recalculate distribution metrics for a given population and distribution data.

Can operate on either q3 or sum_uni distribution data to calculate Q3, q3, and particle diameters corresponding to specific percentiles (x_10, x_50, x_90).

ParametersÔÉÅ

x_uniarray

Unique particle diameters.

q3array, optional

q3 distribution data.

sum_uniarray, optional

sum_uni distribution data.

flagstr, optional

Specifies which metrics to return. Defaults to ‚Äòall‚Äô, can be a comma-separated list of ‚Äòq3‚Äô, ‚ÄòQ3‚Äô, ‚Äòx_10‚Äô, ‚Äòx_50‚Äô, ‚Äòx_90‚Äô.

ReturnsÔÉÅ

tuple

Selected distribution metrics based on the flag. Can include q3, Q3, x_10, x_50, and x_90 values.

calc_Q3(x_uni, q3=None, sum_uni=None)[source]ÔÉÅ

Calculate the cumulative distribution Q3 from q3 or sum_uni distribution data.

calc_sum_uni(Q3, sum_total)[source]ÔÉÅ

Calculate the sum_uni distribution from the Q3 cumulative distribution and total sum.

calc_q3(Q3, x_uni)[source]ÔÉÅ

Calculate the q3 distribution from the Q3 cumulative distribution.
